ENTRY.refkeywords: get_dep get dependent counts array variable data
ENTRY.SYNOPSIS: Return the dependent variable array (e.g., counts) of a data set

DESC.PARA: The get_counts() function returns the dependent variable array of a source or background data set, by data id or bkg_id; it is an alias for the function get_dep(). If a data filter has been applied to the data set in question, e.g. ignore() or notice(), the dependent variable array for either the filtered or unfiltered data set may be returned by setting the 'filter' argument to 'True' or 'False'. If set to 'True', the array returned by get_counts() will be filtered, i.e. the array will be shorter in length than the unfiltered array (not padded with zeros).

LIST.ITEM: id - the id of the data set to use; if not given, uses the default dataset id (id=1 by default, see "ahelp get_default_id")
bkg_id - the id of the background to use, e.g. if more than one background is associated with the data; default=None

DESC.PARA: When called with no arguments, the get_counts() function returns the dependent variable array of the unfiltered default data set.
If a data set ID is supplied to get_counts(), the unfiltered dependent variable array of the specified data set is returned, unless the 'filter' argument is set to 'True'.
DESC.VERBATIM:
sherpa> get_counts(3) array([ 0., 0., 0., ..., 1., 0., 76.])
sherpa> get_counts().size 1024
sherpa> ignore(10.0, 15.0)
sherpa> get_counts(3, filter=True) array([ 0., 0., 0., ..., 1., 0., 76.])
sherpa> get_counts(1, filter=True).size 1018

DESC.PARA: To return the dependent variable array of a background associated with a data set, the background ID must be specified along with the data set ID. Here, the second background loaded for data set 4 is returned by get_counts().

BUGS.PARA: See the bugs pages on the Sherpa website for an up-to-date listing of known bugs.
